title: Effective Instructional Design for Learning Biochemical Non-Covalent Interactions

context.additional_context: Language-integrated applied biochemistry learning program for working professionals. Operated via Problem-Based Learning (PBL) in a BYOD environment, fostering conceptual application skills through team-based projects

learning_goals: Learners can apply and explain the four types of non-covalent interactions (hydrogen bonding, ionic bonding, van der Waals forces, and hydrophobic interactions) to real-world biochemical examples.
Learners can selectively utilize productive failure (PS-I) and explicit instruction (I-PS) strategies based on situational contexts during problem-solving processes.
Learners develop the ability to translate biochemical concepts into verbal expressions (reports/presentations) through PBL tasks.
difficulty: Moderate - Standard complexity with some constraints
